title: Android Weekly Issue #626
description: Articles & Tutorials Sponsored Should you set up a release manager rotation? Mobile releases don’t have to be shouldered by a single person or small group of SMEs using hidden know-how to make the whole thing run. With adequate preparation and support, any mobile engineer (or even a PM or QA) should be able to tackle a release with the right resources in hand. Learn how and why to set up a release rotation for your own team. Android Jetpack Compose Keyboard Cheat Sheet Thomas Bernard shows the different types of keyboard available under Jetpack Compose. How I Finally Memorized Modifier Ordering in Compose Márton Braun shares an explanation to help you with ordering your modifiers correctly. Sponsored Modern mobile observability based on OpenTelemetry Finally, a common language across DevOps and mobile dev teams. With the only open source, OpenTelemetry SDKs specialized for mobile, you can modernize your observability practice with critical mobile signals from real users. The days of siloed tools that don’t share a common set of telemetry are over. Learn more about how to integrate the new OTel SDKs from Embrace today. Everything about customizing coroutine contexts in Kotlin Customizing coroutine contexts in Kotlin is an advanced feature that allows you to control the execution environment of coroutines. Sandeep Kella dives into the details. Accessibility Tests in Compose - Name, Role, Value Eevis Panula shows how to add some accessibility-related tests for three custom components. Dynamic Layouts with ContextualFlowRow and ContextualFlowColumn Donovan LaDuke takes a look at the new layout component for Compose, "Contextual Flow Layout". Jetpack Compose and Nested Scrolling Interoperability Joe Birch examines how to allow a composable to hook into the nested scrolling hierarchy of your layout. Getting started with Jetpack ViewModels and DataStore in Kotlin Multiplatform Richard Woollcott tries AndroidX Jetpack ViewModels and DataStore on a Kotlin Multiplatform app using SwiftUI and Jetpack Compose on iOS and Android. Kotlin MultiPlatform (KMP) Zahra Heydari's step-by-step guide to creating your first cross-platform application that works on Android and iOS platforms. Place a sponsored post Advertise your Android dev course to over 80k readers Libraries & Code bytemask Android Gradle Plugin that masks secret strings for the app in the source code making it difficult to extract from reverse engineering. News Introducing the Google Developer Program: Unlock New Opportunities To help developers build, learn and grow, Google has createdthe Google Developer Program. Tools Roborazzi Plugin for JetBrains IDEs The Roborazzi plugin enhances your development workflow by automatically displaying screenshots related to Roborazzi's screenshot tests within IntelliJ IDEA. Videos & Podcasts The Ultimate Jetpack Compose Creation Checklist! Charfaoui Younes shares a 10-step checklist for Creating Jetpack Compose UIs. Overflow Indicator In Jetpack Compose Daniel Atitienei shows how to add an overflow indicator using Jetpack Compose. Gradle Intro 2: Re-implementing the Kotlin Gradle Plugin from scratch Sebastian Sellmair shows the basics and fundamentals of Gradle by re-implementing the Kotlin Gradle Plugin from scratch. An Introduction to Annotations and Annotation Processors in Kotlin The kt whisperer takes a deep dive into Kotlin annotations and annotation processors. Compose Migration Side Effects - What Can Go Wrong? István Juhos shares scenarios where jumping on the Compose train in a project unprepared might cause long-term headaches. Persist Key-Value pair Locally on both Android/iOS - DataStore KMP Stevdza-San shows how to persist key-value pairs locally on both Android/iOS using DataStore KMP. Kotlin 2.0, Google IO, Android 15 and More Philipp Lackner shares some of the latest advancements in Kotlin and Android. Exploring 'fun code()', The Kotlin Magazine Chet Haase & Marc Reichelt share their journey creating 'fun code()', a resource for Kotlin enthusiasts. Lacey Kobriger: Native Mobile Design Huyen Tue Dao chats with Lacey Kobriger to find out what it means to do native mobile design, what goes into creating delightful experiences, and a whole lot more.

Mobile releases don’t have to be shouldered by a single person or small group of SMEs using hidden know-how to make the whole thing run. With adequate preparation and support, any mobile engineer (or even a PM or QA) should be able to tackle a release with the right resources in hand. Learn how and why to set up a release rotation for your own team.

Finally, a common language across DevOps and mobile dev teams. With the only open source, OpenTelemetry SDKs specialized for mobile, you can modernize your observability practice with critical mobile signals from real users. The days of siloed tools that don’t share a common set of telemetry are over. Learn more about how to integrate the new OTel SDKs from Embrace today.

Zahra Heydari's step-by-step guide to creating your first cross-platform application that works on Android and iOS platforms.

Android Gradle Plugin that masks secret strings for the app in the source code making it difficult to extract from reverse engineering.

The Roborazzi plugin enhances your development workflow by automatically displaying screenshots related to Roborazzi's screenshot tests within IntelliJ IDEA.

Huyen Tue Dao chats with Lacey Kobriger to find out what it means to do native mobile design, what goes into creating delightful experiences, and a whole lot more.
